> I was thinking of saying something along those lines, but "change your

I don't think that you have to change your organization to introduce cruise
control :-)  This tool is well known in the Agile world but it can be used in
any organization, regardless of its "agility".  Simply because you must have a
stable source tree to develop (I think everyone agrees on that).  But how can
you tell if your tree is stable?  Some would say "if it compiles" but I would
add "and if the tests pass".

I would sell the "continuous integration" tool not as an Agile tool, but simply
as a source tree integrity checker.  Of course don't knock on the door of your
manager and tell him that he has no clue, that we must go agile and that's how
we will go there. :-)

I prefer to first use the tools and then go agile.  If you first use JUnit then
refactoring then continuous integration, you will IMO also become agile.  More
slowly I agree, but IMO with less friction (if you are in an "non-agile"
organization).
